{"step_by_step_thinking": "The case presented is about a clicking larynx due to overriding of the hyoid bone and the thyroid lamina. The patient had a partial thyroid laminectomy performed sub-mucoperichondrially which resulted in an immediate and lasting cure. This suggests that the perichondritis of thyroid cartilage was the main issue to be addressed. In neoplastic infiltration of laryngeal cartilages, histocytochemical study shows that neoplastic invasion in cartilage is significantly correlated only to tobacco consumption (P less than .05) and, in regard to glottic tumors, to tumor diameter greater than 3 cm (P less than .01). Since the patient has carcinoma larynx with involvement of anterior commissure and right vocal cord, it is likely that the perichondritis is related to the neoplastic process. Therefore, the main focus should be on managing the underlying cancer rather than just treating the perichondritis.", "answer_choice": "D"}
